Control mapping in virtual reality: effects on spatial presence and controller naturalness

Control mapping in virtual reality: effects on spatial presence and controller naturalness

  • Jonmichael Seibert  ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3195-42321 &
  • Daniel M. Shafer2 

Virtual Reality volume 22, pages79–88(2018)Cite this article

  • 2216 Accesses

  • 22 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

This study explores how a video game player’s sense of being in a game world (i.e., spatial presence) is impacted by the use of a virtual reality head-mounted display (VR HMD). Research focused on VR (as realized with the use of HMDs) has fallen by the wayside since the early 1990s due to the limitations in the technology. With modern reimagining of VR HMDs, there is now an opportunity to reexamine the impact it has on gaming experience. This article explores the results of an experiment in which university students played video games using either a VR HMD or a standard monitor while playing a first-person shooter video game. Control interface was also manipulated between incomplete tangible mapped devices (Razer Hydra) and directionally mapped devices (mouse and keyboard). Results indicated that VR HMDs have a positive impact on a players’ level of spatial presence and feelings of controller naturalness. Controller naturalness also impacted spatial presence regardless of display condition.

Introduction

Virtual reality (VR) technology showed great promise and was of great interest to a wide array of disciplines during the late 1980s and early 1990s. Though it seemed as though VR technology would diffuse into homes, it never materialized (Bracken and Skalski 2010). However, out of this initial interest in VR grew a strong interest in features of video games that create the sense of being in a virtual space, and its varying dimensions (Bracken and Skalski 2010). This interest has led to a great deal of research on the concept of presence as it relates to video games (e.g., Bracken and Skalski 2010; Skalski and Whitbred 2010; Vorderer et al. 2004; Hou et al. 2012); as well as an emerging interest in control mapping (Skalski and Whitbred 2010; Klimmt et al. 2007; Limperos et al. 2011). Despite increased scholarship on the concept of presence and related factors such as control type or mapping (Shafer et al. 2011; Skalski et al. 2011), there is very little current research concerning presence and control mapping in VR applications. Now that advanced VR technology is available to the public in the form of the Oculus Rift and the HTC Vive, this issue is relevant and salient at the present time.

Modern VR controllers

Both Oculus and HTC have released custom controllers alongside their respective VR HMDs. These controllers are designed to provide a natural, lifelike experience in a VR environment (Lang 2016; Robertson 2015). Many games are and will be designed with these new controllers in mind. There is one contemporary controller design that is arguably similar to the hybridized motion–plus–gamepad controls that the Oculus and HTC devices are trying to achieve: the Razer Hydra. The Hydra is a dual-wielded motion-sensing game controller. Each ergonomic control stick has sensors that interact with a base station that tracks their movement. The controllers boast buttons and thumb sticks for additional functionality and control, and give users of gamepads some familiar reference points (Shoemaker 2011). Unfortunately, the Rader Hydra appears to fall short of a true analogue to the upcoming Oculus Touch and HTC Vive controllers. According to Nabioyuni and Bowman (2015), VR interaction technique design can be described in terms of Interaction Fidelity. It was assumed that, like the Oculus Touch and HTC Vive, the Razer Hydra would provide high levels of Interaction Fidelity, and would be what Nabioyni and Bowman describe as a Natural design approach. In reality, the Razer Hydra has much lower Interaction Fidelity and according to Nabioyni and Bowman’s work uses a combination of non-natural and semi-natural design. Due to this, the Razer Hydra was seen as less natural than traditional game controls. Vorderer (2000) argues that as a player becomes more accustomed to the activities needed to control a video game, those activities become natural and effortless to perform. For example, the familiar mouse and keyboard interface that PC users are accustomed to, with experience, seems very natural. Adapting to a new sort of interface, albeit more naturally mapped, may actually take much thought and dedication. Vorderer (2000) asserts that this additional thought and effort necessarily devoted to learning a different control method may break players out of immersive experience of the game world. One reviewer of the Hydra, an experienced gamer, exemplified this experience in reporting that “After nearly two decades of using a keyboard and mouse for my first-person shooter skills, adjusting to the world of virtual reality and motion controllers that require my full, physical, close-to-reality movements is quite a shock to the senses” (Garreffa 2014 p. 3).

In light of this evidence, it will be useful to examine how a motion-sensing control method (i.e., the Razer Hydra) similar to those proposed by Oculus and HTC compares to the traditional and familiar mouse and keyboard control method for a first-person shooter video game in terms of controller naturalness and spatial presence outcomes. In order to provide a complete picture of the possible perceptual differences each control method might bring out, this study will test each method used to control an FPS using both VR and non-VR displays.

Virtual reality technology

VR technology is a tool by which humans can directly interact with computers in order to solve far more complex problems than by using strictly traditional interface methods (Burdea and Coiffet 2003). One key part of VR is software capable of emulating realistic environments (Burdea and Coiffet 2003). Developers now have the ability to create stunningly realistic worlds populated with artificial intelligences who behave in believable manners (Tamborini and Bowman 2010).

Steuer (1992) argues that “A ‘virtual reality’ is defined as a real or simulated environment in which the perceiver experiences telepresence” (p. 7). This conceptual understanding of VR allows for a far broader interpretation of what constitutes a virtual reality. Steuer (1992) defines VR in terms of vividness and interactivity. Vividness is described as how fully a technology represents the environment it is simulating to a user across multiple sensory channels (Steuer 1992). Vividness consists of both breadth (the ability of the medium to stimulate several senses simultaneously) and depth (the quality of the image or experience; Steuer 1992). Interactivity is defined as the extent a user is capable of modifying the form and content of the virtual environment they are in (Steuer 1992). Interactivity, according to Steuer (1992), consists of three factors: speed, range and mapping. Speed is the rate that input is assimilated into the environment. This would be impacted by the capabilities of the hardware used for the experience. Range is the breadth of possible actions a user can take, which is determined by the software and the control interface’s relationship with the software. Mapping is ability for a system to have a set of controls that translate into actions that make sense to the user (Steuer 1992). Mapping is determined in large part by the control device and how it interfaces with the software—specifically for video games, how the activation of controls translates into movement and actions in the displayed environment.

With Steuer’s conceptualization of virtual reality, it becomes reasonable to state that vividness can be related to the sense of presence one feels in a virtual environment, while interactivity is directly related to control mapping and naturalness. Therefore, in the present study, we propose to measure user experience in terms of vividness (operationalized as spatial presence) and interactivity (operationalized as controller naturalness) as Steuer (1992) suggests.

Defining presence

According to Steuer (1992), “Telepresence is defined as the experience of presence in an environment by means of a communication medium” (p. 6). What Steuer is referencing has come to be known as “spatial presence” in other work (e.g., Wirth et al. 2007). As Wirth et al. (2007) state, citing the International Society for Presence Research, spatial presence is “a sense of being there” (Wirth et al. 2007; ISPR 2000); The ISPR goes on to define spatial presence thus: “‘Spatial presence’, ‘physical presence,’ ‘a sense of physical space,’ ‘perceptual immersion,’ ‘transportation’ and ‘a sense of being there’ occur when part or all of a person’s perception fails to accurately acknowledge the role of technology that makes it appear that s/he is in a physical location and environment different from her/his actual location and environment in the physical world” (ISPR 2000 para 7a). For the purposes of this study, we specifically measure and work with the concept of spatial presence. There are certainly other dimensions of the concept of presence, but spatial presence is the most salient to the present investigation.

Much spatial presence research has focused on image size, image quality and sound quality (e.g., Skalski and Whitbred 2010; Hou et al. 2012). There has also been research done specifically on VR HMD technology (Tamborini et al. 2004). Tamborini et al. (2004) showed that being in a VR environment improved a user’s feelings of presence only slightly, and not enough to be statistically significant. Additionally, Juan and Pérez (2009) conducted a study which examined participant’s levels of presence and anxiety when exposed to acrophobic (fear relating to heights) environments in a virtual environment using either an HMD or a Computer Automatic Virtual Environment (CAVE) as a display. A CAVE is a display where an image is projected on to the surfaces of an enclosed room. In this study, participants were shown to be in a room where the floor suddenly fell away from them. Participants using the CAVE reported higher levels of anxiety and presence than those using an HMD. Baños et al. (2004) showed that between an HMD and traditional display types, the only difference among the conditions was in the category of “negative effects” with the HMD having the most undesirable effects on participants. Slater et al. (1996), however, showed that participants who viewed a Tri-Dimensional Chess board using an HMD were able to reproduce the board better than those who viewed the board using a traditional display.

Other studies have discussed the relationship between VR and the concept of presence (Schuemie et al. 2001; Slater et al. 1995), but have not directly tested spatial presence in VR versus a non-VR environment.

Hou et al. (2012) studied the effects that distance from the screen and the screen’s size had on presence. In this study, the researchers compared two groups of subjects playing the same video game, with screen size and distance from the screen being manipulated. Condition one used an 81 in. screen viewed from 51.5 in. and condition two used a 12.7 in. screen viewed from 36.5 in. The findings of this study showed that players using the larger screen experienced higher levels of presence.

IJsselsteijn et al. (2001) examined the effects of stereoscopic displays (a technology used in modern HMDs) had on presence. Their findings indicated that stereoscopic 3D images had a significant effect on the levels of presence experienced by participants.

It is clear from the existing literature that the type of display used does have an impact on the levels of presence a player experiences. Bracken and Skalski (2010) and Skalski and Whitbred (2010) manipulated the quality of the images (standard definition vs. high definition), not the actual type of the display they used. The findings of Hou et al. (2012), however, show that there is a link between the type of display used and a player’s experience of presence. It is with this in mind that we ask the following research question:

RQ1

Will using a virtual reality HMD produce higher levels of spatial presence than using a traditional display device such as a television or computer screen?

Control methods and natural mapping

Norman (1986, 1988) produced some of the earliest work concerning the ideas of natural mapping. He explains how humans use control interfaces to achieve tasks. Norman describes the idea of using close analogues of what the user is attempting to accomplish when they interact with a control interface. Research into the topic of game controls have found that control method has a large impact on players’ enjoyment of games (Klimmt et al. 2007; Limperos et al. 2011).

Skalski et al. (2011) also approach the topic of natural mapping in relation to video games. They describe a typology of natural mapping which includes (1) directional natural mapping, (2) incomplete tangible natural mapping, (3) kinesic natural mapping and (4) realistic tangible natural mapping. Directional mapping is the most prevalent form of mapping seen today. It the simple (but ostensibly unnatural) “press left to walk left” or “pull the trigger button to attack” kind of control scheme found assigned to any gamepad. Even though, as Skalski et al. (2011) point out, the act of pressing a button to make an avatar walk forward is not inherently natural, it makes sense to have directions mapped out somewhat naturally, such as configuring a keyboard so that pressing W makes a character walk forward, while pressing S, which is located “behind” the W key, makes a character walk backward.

The Nintendo Wii was one of the first to successfully challenge directional natural mapping. The Wii employs what Skalski et al. (2011) called incomplete tangible mapping. It works by giving players a controller that partially emulates the feel of what they’re doing in a game. In Wii golf or baseball, the controller is swung like a club or a bat, but it is only partially representative of a real club or bat; not being of the same size or weight.

Microsoft’s Kinect device makes use of kinesic mapping, which allows users to perform the near-exact actions they want their avatar to do without need of a controller. Instead, the body is tracked and those movements are translated into movement in the virtual world. This type of mapping is inexact, because there are no tangible objects to hold. For instance, sword fighting in a kinesic control environment is done with empty hands, not holding a sword or sword-like object.

Realistic tangible mapping makes use of a tangible, realistic analogue to what the player is using in whatever virtual reality they are engaged in. A good example would be an arcade game where players use a gun-shaped controller to aim and fire at onscreen enemies (Skalski et al. 2011). The use of this type of realistic tangible mapping has thus far been limited to arcade games or, very rarely, a few home console games. However, due to the surge in development of VR technology and new, related advances in motion tracking capability, it is possible to create controllers which fall into the category of realistic tangible natural mapping.

Skalski et al. (2011) explored the influence these different types of controls had on both spatial presence and enjoyment. Their study consisted of two experiments; both focused on varying control types and examined differences in levels of presence and enjoyment. In the first experiment, participants played a golf game using either a Nintendo Wii motion-based controller or a standard PlayStation 2 gamepad. In the second experiment, participants played a driving game using a steering wheel controller, a keyboard, a gamepad, or a joystick. Both experiments showed that using the more naturally mapped controllers yielded higher levels of presence than the other control types.

Shafer et al. (2011) also considered control types and their influence on spatial presence. In their study, control type was categorized in terms of interactivity. They list the PlayStation Move and Microsoft Kinect as high interactivity, the Wii remote as medium interactivity and standard gamepad controls as low interactivity. Their study consisted of two experiments: the first investigated these three control types across a driving game and a golf game; the second compared the control types using a boxing game. Both studies compared levels of spatial presence between the different conditions. Their findings were that greater interactivity leads to higher levels of spatial presence. They also found that higher levels of spatial presence predict higher levels of enjoyment (Shafer et al. 2011).

Slater et al. (1995) and Usoh et al. (1999) also explored how more natural movements (e.g., walking) influence sense of presence. The Usoh et al. (1999) experiment compared walking in place, real walking, and virtual flying as methods of locomotion in a virtual environment. Real walking was deemed simpler, more straightforward, and more natural than either flying or walking in place. In a similar study using a CAVE environment, McMahan et al. (2012) found that a high-fidelity display paired with a highly interactive and responsive interface (i.e., more natural) produced significantly higher levels of presence and engagement than low resolution graphics and a less natural interface.

The literature concerning controller types as they relate to spatial presence is fairly clear. Control types which are more naturally mapped (Skalski et al. 2011; Usoh et al. 1999) or more interactive (Shafer et al. 2011) lead to players experiencing higher levels of spatial presence. However, Vorderer’s (2000) concern that unfamiliar control methods, despite their superiority in realism and tangibility may not surpass the ease of use and immersive possibilities of familiar control methods should be taken seriously. As such, we propose the following research question:

RQ2

Which control method will participants find more natural—the directional mapping control method (familiar mouse and keyboard interface) or the incomplete tangible mapping control method (Razer Hydra)?

Regardless of which control method is deemed more natural, past research shows that controller naturalness positively impacts spatial presence. Therefore, it is predicted that:

H1

Controller naturalness will produce higher levels of spatial presence regardless of display type.

This investigation will also explore what influence the VR HMD will have on a player’s feeling of controller naturalness. Using a VR HMD is a new experience for players and will require an adjustment on their part in how they control the game. With that in mind, the following research question is posed:

RQ3

Will playing an FPS using a VR HMD impact perceived controller naturalness?

Covariates

A potential problem to account for is that of cybersickness related to use of VR HMDs. Cybersickness is a major drawback to the use of VR technology. Cybersickness manifests with symptoms similar to motion sickness, including nausea and vomiting, disorientation and tiredness, headaches, and eyestrain (LaViola 2000; Shafer et al. 2015). Vinson et al. (2012) state that “Cybersickness is essentially a barrier to both adoption and production of VR technologies” (p. 69). A number of studies have examined cybersickness in virtual environments (Kennedy et al. 2000; LaViola 2000; Stanney and Hash 1998; Vinson et al. 2012); as such, including it as a covariate in the present study is necessary (for further reading on the problem of cybersickness as it relates to modern VR HMDs, see Shafer et al. 2015).

Methods

In a 2 (Standard Display, VR Display) × 2 (mouse and keyboard, Razer Hydra) between subjects factorial design, participants were randomly assigned to one of four gaming conditions. Immediately after exposure to the game, participants were directed to the online questionnaire containing the items for the dependent and independent variables as well as demographic questions. Total experiment time was approximately 45 min.

Participants

Participants were 207 undergraduate students from various courses at a research university in the southern-central United States. Participants were offered extra credit for their participation (alongside other options for extra credit). The sample was about equal in number of males (n = 107) 51.7% and females (n = 100) 48.3%. The average age was 20.3 years. Participants were asked how often they played computer games. About two-thirds of the sample (66.7%) reported that they play computer games infrequently (never or only once or twice a month), while the remaining third (33.3%) reported that they play quite often (often but less than 50% of days, about 50% of days, or every day).

For the study, participants were randomly assigned to play a first-person shooter video game using either a standard monitor or a VR HMD—the Oculus Rift DK-1. The device has a high field of view screen and is capable of low latency head tracking.

Although not everyone was assigned to use the Oculus Rift, they all had an opportunity to play the game with it after their main study session was complete in order to avoid the possibility of inequality of benefits.

Stimulus and systems

Participants all played the game Half Life 2 and were randomly assigned to one of four conditions: Condition one (n = 55): standard monitor display with mouse and keyboard controls; Condition two (n = 49): Oculus Rift with mouse and keyboard controls; Condition three: standard monitor display with Razer Hydra controls (n = 55); Condition four (n = 48): Oculus Rift with Razer Hydra controls. All four conditions played the same segment of Half Life 2. Half Life 2 is a first-person shooter in an urban setting. All players began equipped with a pistol and a crowbar. The segment of game play required the player to travel through the sewer system of a city. To successfully traverse this environment, players needed to be able to climb ladders, break obstacles, solve basic puzzles and fight armed enemies. Players used a gaming station consisting of a 18.28 cm (32 in.) HDTV television monitor and a Dell computer with an Intel quad-core 3.2 Ghz processor, 8 mb RAM, and an Nvidia GeForce GTX 780 video card. The control mapping scheme for each controller type can be found in Table 1.

Procedure

After giving informed consent, participants were asked to watch a 5 min video tutorial explaining the controls of the game and where to proceed in the game. Upon completion of the video, participants were given a brief demonstration of the game’s controls. Then they played the game for 20 min. Upon completion of the game play, they answered the questionnaire which assessed the main variables in the study. Each full session including the experimental tasks and free play time lasted a maximum of 60 min.

Measures

Spatial presence was measured by the spatial presence subscale of ITC-Sense of Presence Inventory (ITC-SOPI: Lessiter et al. 2001). This measure was composed of 19 items such as “I felt I could interact with the displayed environment.” Each item was measured on a five-point scale from “strongly disagree” to “strongly agree.” Scores were produced by summing and averaging the scores from each item. The scale had an observed Cronbach’s α = .93.

Cybersickness was measured by the negative effects subscale of ITC-SOPI (Lessiter et al. 2001). This measure was composed of six items such as “I felt disoriented.” Each item was measured on a five-point scale from “strongly disagree” to “strongly agree.” Scores were produced by summing and averaging the scores from each item. This measure included six items and had an observed Cronbach’s α = .92.

Perceived controller naturalness was measured using five items taken from (Skalski et al. 2011). Some sample items are: “The game controls seemed natural” and “The game environment was manipulated in a lifelike manner.” Each item was measured on a seven-point scale from “strongly disagree” to “strongly agree.” Scores were produced by summing and averaging the scores from each item. This measure had an observed Cronbach’s α = .82.

Results

RQ1 asked if playing a game with a virtual reality HMD would produce higher levels of spatial presence than playing a game with a traditional flat display (Figs. 1, 2, 3). A univariate analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) was performed (via a general linear model procedure), and the results indicated that players in the virtual reality condition reported significantly higher levels of spatial presence than players in the standard display condition (see Table 2), controlling for perceived naturalness and cybersickness, and frequency of computer game play; F (1, 196) = 18.15, p < .001, η 2 = .09 (Levene’s test indicated equal variances, F (1, 198) = .084, p = .772).

The analysis controlled for cybersickness, controller naturalness and frequency of computer game play. Controller naturalness and cybersickness were significant covariates in the model (see Table 3).

RQ2 asked which control method (a directionally mapped mouse and keyboard or an incomplete tangible mapped Razer Hydra) players would find more natural. In accordance with Vorderer’s (2000) contention that the familiar may seem more natural than ostensibly more naturally mapped control methods, the directionally mapped mouse and keyboard interface was judged significantly more natural than the incomplete-tangibly mapped Razer Hydra (see Table 4), F (1, 196) = 4.29, p = .04, η 2 = .021 (Levene’s test indicated equal variances, F (1, 198) = .90, p = .343).

The GLM analysis revealed that the use of one controller type over another did not necessarily determine the level of naturalness a player felt. Regression analysis results indicate that control type can only explain approximately 2% of the variance in feelings of controller naturalness (see η 2 value for controller type in Table 5). What this infers is that some players found the Hydra to be the more natural interface, and some players found the mouse and keyboard to be the more natural interface. We cannot confidently claim, therefore, due to the low explained variance, that one control method was judged to be overwhelmingly more natural, although the mouse and keyboard interface was rated statistically the more natural control method. Each variable included in the model only accounted for about 2% of the variance in controller naturalness.

H1 predicted that using a control method judged to be more natural would lead to higher levels of spatial presence across display conditions. The ANCOVA procedure used to evaluate RQ1 was also used to evaluate the impact of controller naturalness on spatial presence. Results showed that spatial presence values were highly dependent on feelings of controller naturalness, controlling for cybersickness. Over 40% of the variance in spatial presence could be explained by feelings of naturalness, β = .37 (SE = .04), t = 11.46, p < .001, η 2 = .40. Therefore, H1 is supported.

RQ3 asked if using a VR HMD would impact player reports of controller naturalness. An ANCOVA (GLM) with controller naturalness as the dependent variable and cybersickness and game experience as covariates indicated that players felt the controls were more natural in the VR HMD condition than in the standard display condition (see Table 6), F (1, 196) = 4.22, p = .041, η 2 = .021 (Levene’s test indicated equal variances, F (1, 198) = .006, p = .938).

These results indicate that playing with a VR HMD resulted in more perceived controller naturalness than playing with a standard display, regardless of the control device actually used. Cybersickness was found to be a significant negative covariate in the model, β = −.27 (SE = .09), t = −2.99, p = .003, η 2 = .04.

Discussion

Implications of research questions and hypotheses

This study yielded informative results with regard to how the use of VR HMDs affects spatial presence and controller naturalness, and how controller naturalness impacts spatial presence. Also, as previous research on spatial presence and display has shown (Bracken and Skalski 2010; Skalski and Whitbred 2010; Hou et al. 2012), display type had a marked impact on spatial presence. Specifically, using a VR HMD increased spatial presence in a significantly positive way, which VR developers have predicted since the outset of the development of the current generation of this technology (Oculus Rift n.d.). Results indicated that cybersickness did not make a significant impact on spatial presence. This does not mean that no one felt symptoms of cybersickness as they played; it simply indicates that players felt present in the game environment in spite of any feelings of sickness.

Skalski et al. (2011) published their controller naturalness typology, which was described in an earlier section. According to their typology, the incomplete tangible controller (Razer Hydra) should have been perceived as more natural than the directional controller (mouse and keyboard). However, results of this study indicate that more players, on average, felt that the mouse and keyboard were more natural. This result may be due to the Razer Hydra not being a natural control type as originally hoped. According to the concept of interaction fidelity forwarded by Nabioyni and Bowman (2015), the Razer Hydra appears to fall into the classification of semi-natural as opposed to natural. This could have led to participants viewing the Razer Hydra controls as less natural than the standard keyboard and mouse controls. Vorderer (2000) forwards his notion that players become accustomed to the predominant control method to the point that that control method becomes natural and intuitive makes sense when applied to the results of the present study. It would seem that most players found the mouse and keyboard interface more natural than the Razer Hydra. As such, the variable perceived naturalness became more important than the control device that was actually used. Perceived naturalness was only weakly impacted by controller type.

Perceived naturalness, regardless of what controller type was used, significantly increased players’ sense of spatial presence, indicating that if controllers do indeed encourage natural, lifelike movements that are accurately translated into the virtual environment, and if players become accustomed to their use, those controllers will encourage VR users to feel more present in the game environment. But if, as results from participants in this study imply, those controllers require a steep learning curve as users become accustomed to their use, such feelings of presence may need time to develop.

The answer to research question 3 is that, no matter what controller was being used, players reported more controller naturalness in the VR HMD condition. This result aligns well with previous findings that show that higher levels of controller naturalness along with a large-screen display resulted in increased presence for gamers (Kim and Sundar 2013).

Limitations, conclusions and future research

We have demonstrated in this study that VR HMDs paired with control interfaces that seem natural and intuitive to the user are powerful gateways to immersive virtual worlds. Players using VR HMDs experienced significantly higher levels of spatial presence than players using a standard display. However, the VR HMD could only explain about 10% of the variance in spatial presence. How natural the controller felt (regardless of whether the controller was more naturally mapped or not) was a more important determinant of spatial presence, explaining more than 40% of the variance. The results seem to indicate that using a VR HMD encouraged players to perceive their control method as more natural, which in turn determined how present in the game world they felt. These results should offer hope to those developing new, naturally mapped controllers for use in VR. Players respond well to controller they perceive as natural, becoming more present in the game world as a result. However, our results also may indicate that such development should be approached carefully. The ostensibly more naturally mapped Razer Hydra used for this experiment was generally perceived as less natural than the directionally mapped mouse and keyboard. New naturally mapped controllers should be so responsive and intuitive that using them becomes second nature very quickly. It seems that in our experiment, participants found the Razer Hydra’s interface difficult to learn, while the mouse and keyboard was familiar. One potential limitation of the study is that our procedure does not take player adaptation to or experience with each control scheme into account. In future studies, this variable should be assessed using a repeated measures design.

Future research should explore the relationships between the variables we have tested here more fully; including them in a predictive model that can analyze all variables in question simultaneously. Shafer et al. (2011) proposed and then tested a model that may be applicable to VR experiences (Shafer et al. 2014). Their model considered how perceived interactivity, perceived reality, and spatial presence all work together to determine how enjoyable a game is. The model could certainly be expanded to include controller naturalness, and could include cybersickness as a possible covariate. Such research would further our efforts to understand the process of experiencing games and other content in VR greatly.

Also of interest is how the brain processes VR environments from a neurological standpoint. Knowledge of which regions of the brain process signals generated from using VR would be invaluable in understanding how VR applications may continue to be used in therapy and rehabilitation, as well as for entertainment. As such, future research should include EEG and fMRI data from users of VR HMDs. VR has arrived, and scholars must now work to understand what the implications of its use are, both in the short term and in the long term.

Appendix: Measures

Appendix: Measures

Note: the ITC-Sense of Presence Inventory is bound by copyright law and cannot be reprinted here. We suggest contacting the original authors for more details (Lessiter et al. 2001).

Skalski Perceived Controller Naturalness Scale:

  1. 1.

    The game controls seemed natural.

  2. 2.

    The actions used to interact with the game environment were similar to the actions that would be used to do the same things in the real world.

  3. 3.

    The game interface was not realistic.

  4. 4.

    The game environment was manipulated in a lifelike manner.

  5. 5.

    The actions I performed with the controller were closely connected to the actions happening in the game environment.

  6. 6.

    The actions used to control the game seemed natural.
